io.reinert.gdeferred

Interface Promise<D,F,P>

  • Type Parameters:
    D - Type used for done(DoneCallback)
    F - Type used for fail(FailCallback)
    P - The type of the progress notification
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Deferred<D,F,P>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractPromise, DeferredObject, FilteredPromise, PipedPromise

    public interface Promise<D,F,P>
    Promise interface to observe when some action has occurred on the corresponding Deferred object.

    A promise object should be obtained from Deferred.promise(), or by using DeferredManager. 

     
 Deferred deferredObject = new DeferredObject();
 Promise promise = deferredObject.promise();
 promise.done(new DoneCallback() {
   void onDone(Object result) {
       // Done!
   }
 });

 // another thread using the same deferredObject
 deferredObject.resolve("OK");
    Author:
    Ray Tsang, Danilo Reinert
    See Also:
    Deferred.resolve(Object), Deferred.reject(Object), Deferred.notify(Object)

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static class  Promise.State
      State of a Promise

    • Method Detail

      • always

        Promise<D,F,P> always(AlwaysCallback<D,F> callback)
        This method will register AlwaysCallback so that when it's always triggered regardless of whether the corresponding Deferred object was resolved or rejected.

        You can register multiple AlwaysCallback by calling the method multiple times. The order of callback trigger is based on the order you call this method. 

         
 promise.always(new AlwaysCallback(){
   void onAlways(Context context, Object result, Object rejection) {
     if (context.getState() == State.RESOLVED) {
       // do something w/ result
     } else {
       // do something w/ rejection
     }
   }
 });
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to be executed when the promise is done or failed
        Returns:
        The current promise
        See Also:
        Deferred.resolve(Object), Deferred.reject(Object)

      • done

        Promise<D,F,P> done(DoneCallback<D> callback)
        This method will register DoneCallback so that when a Deferred object is resolved (Deferred.resolve(Object)), DoneCallback will be triggered.

        You can register multiple DoneCallback by calling the method multiple times. The order of callback trigger is based on the order you call this method. 

         
 promise.progress(new DoneCallback(){
   void onDone(Object done) {
     ...
   }
 });
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to be executed when the promise is done
        Returns:
        The current promise
        See Also:
        Deferred.resolve(Object)

      • fail

        Promise<D,F,P> fail(FailCallback<F> callback)
        This method will register FailCallback so that when a Deferred object is rejected (Deferred.reject(Object)), FailCallback will be triggered.

        You can register multiple FailCallback by calling the method multiple times. The order of callback trigger is based on the order you call this method. 

         
 promise.fail(new FaillCallback(){
   void onFail(Object rejection) {
     ...
   }
 });
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to be executed when the promise has failed
        Returns:
        The current promise
        See Also:
        Deferred.reject(Object)

      • isPending

        boolean isPending()
        Returns:
        true if is pending, false otherwise
        See Also:
        Promise.State.PENDING

      • isRejected

        boolean isRejected()
        Returns:
        true if is rejected, false otherwise
        See Also:
        Promise.State.REJECTED

      • isResolved

        boolean isResolved()
        Returns:
        true if is resolved, false otherwise
        See Also:
        Promise.State.RESOLVED

      • progress

        Promise<D,F,P> progress(ProgressCallback<P> callback)
        This method will register ProgressCallback so that when a Deferred object is notified of progress (Deferred.notify(Object)), ProgressCallback will be triggered.

        You can register multiple ProgressCallback by calling the method multiple times. The order of callback trigger is based on the order you call this method. 

         
 promise.progress(new ProgressCallback(){
   void onProgress(Object progress) {
     // e.g., update progress in the GUI while the background task is still running.
   }
 });
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to be executed when a progress notification is sent
        Returns:
        The current promise
        See Also:
        Deferred.notify(Object)

      • state

        Promise.State state()

      • then

        Promise<D,F,P> then(DoneCallback<D> doneCallback)
        Equivalent to done(DoneCallback).
        Parameters:
        doneCallback - done(DoneCallback)
        Returns:
        the same promise

      • then

        Promise<D,F,P> then(DoneCallback<D> doneCallback,
                  FailCallback<F> failCallback)
        Equivalent to done(DoneCallback) and then FailCallback.
        Parameters:
        doneCallback - done(DoneCallback)
        failCallback - fail(FailCallback)
        Returns:
        the same promise

      • then

        Promise<D,F,P> then(DoneCallback<D> doneCallback,
                  FailCallback<F> failCallback,
                  ProgressCallback<P> progressCallback)
        Equivalent to done(DoneCallback), then FailCallback, then progress(ProgressCallback).
        Parameters:
        doneCallback - done(DoneCallback)
        failCallback - fail(FailCallback)
        progressCallback - progress(ProgressCallback)
        Returns:
        the same promise

      • then

        <D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> Promise<D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> then(DoneFilter<D,D_OUT> doneFilter,
                                                  FailFilter<F,F_OUT> failFilter)
        Equivalent to then(doneFilter, failFilter, null).
        Parameters:
        doneFilter - the done filter callback
        failFilter - the fail filter callback
        Returns:
        the output promise from executed filter
        See Also:
        #then(DoneFilter, FailFilter, ProgressFilter)}

      • then

        <D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> Promise<D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> then(DoneFilter<D,D_OUT> doneFilter,
                                                  FailFilter<F,F_OUT> failFilter,
                                                  ProgressFilter<P,P_OUT> progressFilter)
        If any of the filter is not specified, a default No Op filter would be used. This is also known as "piping", or "chaining" of callbacks and being able to modify the return value. 

         
 Deferred deferred = new DeferredObject();
 Promise promise = deferred.promise();
 Promise filtered = promise.then(new DoneFilter() {
   Integer filterDone(Integer result) {
     return result * 10;
   }
 });

 filtered.then(new DoneCallback() {
   void onDone(Integer result) {
     System.out.println(result);
   }
 });

 deferred.resolve(1); // prints 10
        Parameters:
        doneFilter - the done filter callback
        failFilter - the fail filter callback
        progressFilter - the progress filter callback
        Returns:
        the output promise from executed filter

      • then

        <D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> Promise<D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> then(DonePipe<D,D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> donePipe)
        Equivalent to then(DonePipe, null, null).
        Parameters:
        donePipe - the done pipe callback
        Returns:
        the output promise returned from executed pipe

      • then

        <D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> Promise<D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> then(DonePipe<D,D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> donePipe,
                                                  FailPipe<F,D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> failPipe)
        Equivalent to then(DonePipe, FailPipe, null).
        Parameters:
        donePipe - the done pipe callback
        failPipe - the fail pipe callback
        Returns:
        the output promise returned from executed pipe

      • then

        <D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> Promise<D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> then(DonePipe<D,D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> donePipe,
                                                  FailPipe<F,D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> failPipe,
                                                  ProgressPipe<P,D_OUT,F_OUT,P_OUT> progressPipe)
        This method is similar to jQuery's pipe() method, where a new Promise is returned by the the pipe filter instead of the original. This is useful to handle return values and then rewiring it to different callbacks. 

         
 promise.then(new DonePipe() {
   Deferred pipeDone(Integer result) {
     // Reject values greater than 100
     if (result > 100) {
       return new DeferredObject().reject("Failed");
     } else {
       return new DeferredObject().resolve(result);
     }
   }
 }).done(...)
 .fail(...);
        Parameters:
        donePipe - the done pipe callback
        failPipe - the fail pipe callback
        progressPipe - the progress pipe callback
        Returns:
        the output promise returned from executed pipe
